channel.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
channel.description: Anyone know how to do the search by rank like RuneScape? I'm just too stupid, I've tried to figure it out. Who knows, maybe after I post this I fix it. So, if anyone could give me the function or whatever for RS's search rank, that would be great.

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @wihbe wihbe
item.description:
@wihbe wrote:

mysql> SET @rownum := 0;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> SELECT * FROM ( SELECT @rownum := @rownum + 1 AS rank, username FROM highscores WHERE skill = 0 ORDER BY level DESC, exp DESC LIMIT 1000 ) AS ranked_highscores WHERE rank >= 10 AND rank <= 20;
+------+--------------+
| rank | username     |
+------+--------------+
|   10 | i_0wn_u_n00b |
|   11 | ciuschi      |
|   12 | phpkk        |
|   13 | deathnote777 |
|   14 | karm1     |
|   15 | decade       |
|   16 | big_fred40   |
|   17 | iillkkoouu   |
|   18 | olddark1     |
|   19 | ralphe10     |
|   20 | soturi1      |
+------+--------------+
11 rows in set (0.02 sec)

mysql>

Karm1 was my irl brother account

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @sageofmali sageofmali
item.description:
@sageofmali wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:20, topic:382667”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=478460.msg3503618#msg3503618 date=1297970289]
I doubt that would work

EDIT: And if it did, I think my way would still be faster Could easily be adapted to something like
mysql_data_seek($query_result, $rank_number-25)

then a 50 count loop or something to do it exactly the same as runescape
[/quote]

It does work (the original one I posted is being used live on the emps-scape site as I said, and there was one tiny modification to search by the user’s rank instead of their name). Also it is capable of returning results in a range like so:

mysql> SET @rownum := 0;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> SELECT * FROM ( SELECT @rownum := @rownum + 1 AS rank, username FROM highscores WHERE skill = 0 ORDER BY level DESC, exp DESC LIMIT 1000 ) AS ranked_highscores WHERE rank >= 10 AND rank <= 20;
+------+--------------+
| rank | username     |
+------+--------------+
|   10 | i_0wn_u_n00b |
|   11 | ciuschi      |
|   12 | phpkk        |
|   13 | deathnote777 |
|   14 | karm1        |
|   15 | decade       |
|   16 | big_fred40   |
|   17 | iillkkoouu   |
|   18 | olddark1     |
|   19 | ralphe10     |
|   20 | soturi1      |
+------+--------------+
11 rows in set (0.02 sec)

mysql>

The trouble with your code is that it’ll cause a lot of traffic between PHP and MySQL since the entire table has to be sent between them. Also, PHP is usually configured to run in small amounts of memory (perhaps 8 - 32 MB in general) and any more than that will cause errors. With a small private server this isn’t an issue. However, the high scores table is around 25 MB on Emps so we’d be getting close to that barrier (and 25 MB going between PHP and MySQL each time a user uses the highscores would probably be a big problem).[/quote]
Uhmm, okay. I still can’t figure out how to do this.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:13, topic:382667”]I doubt that would work

EDIT: And if it did, I think my way would still be faster Could easily be adapted to something like
mysql_data_seek($query_result, $rank_number-25)

then a 50 count loop or something to do it exactly the same as runescape :P[/quote]

It does work (the original one I posted is being used live on the emps-scape site as I said, and there was one tiny modification to search by the user’s rank instead of their name). Also it is capable of returning results in a range like so:

mysql> SET @rownum := 0;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.00 sec)

mysql> SELECT * FROM ( SELECT @rownum := @rownum + 1 AS rank, username FROM highscores WHERE skill = 0 ORDER BY level DESC, exp DESC LIMIT 1000 ) AS ranked_highscores WHERE rank >= 10 AND rank <= 20;
+------+--------------+
| rank | username     |
+------+--------------+
|   10 | i_0wn_u_n00b |
|   11 | ciuschi      |
|   12 | phpkk        |
|   13 | deathnote777 |
|   14 | karm1        |
|   15 | decade       |
|   16 | big_fred40   |
|   17 | iillkkoouu   |
|   18 | olddark1     |
|   19 | ralphe10     |
|   20 | soturi1      |
+------+--------------+
11 rows in set (0.02 sec)

mysql>

The trouble with your code is that it’ll cause a lot of traffic between PHP and MySQL since the entire table has to be sent between them. Also, PHP is usually configured to run in small amounts of memory (perhaps 8 - 32 MB in general) and any more than that will cause errors. With a small private server this isn’t an issue. However, the high scores table is around 25 MB on Emps so we’d be getting close to that barrier (and 25 MB going between PHP and MySQL each time a user uses the highscores would probably be a big problem).

EDIT: in fact in this case you probably won’t need a nested query. But you do need it to find someone’s rank given their username

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“sageofmali, post:16, topic:382667”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=478460.msg3503790#msg3503790 date=1297981502]
The best way to search a database actually avoids SQL all together. You should use Sphinx. I use it for the search both on the forum and the serverstatus page, it dropped the load substantially and makes searches more accurate and basically instant. It’s awesome!
[/quote]
Thanks! Do I download it, or what?[/quote]

It’s slightly more complicated than just searching with SQL queries, but worth it if you are going to be doing a lot of searches. You probably want to research it a little first, you may not even be able to use it (like if you use shared hosting).

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:11, topic:382667”]Wait, does that search through the database and then pull out the result of a certain row number? That’s what he wants He wants like:

Search for rank: X
And then it searches the database for the person ranked X.[/quote]

No it doesn’t - it returns the rank for the user you specify. But I think it could be adapted like this:

SET @rownum := 0;
SELECT * FROM ( SELECT @rownum := @rownum + 1 AS rank, username FROM highscores WHERE skill = ? ORDER BY level DESC, exp DESC LIMIT 1000 ) AS ranked_highscores WHERE rank = ?;

(not tested that :p)

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank

Search for rank: X
And then it searches the database for the person ranked X.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Hiscores Search by rank
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:9, topic:382667”]‘Johns?’ Who are you talking about…

[quote author=Graham link=topic=478460.msg3503391#msg3503391 date=1297939662]

Do not listen to Vain, he is an idiot making up answers to increase his post count.

What you want do is use:
$query_result = mysql_query(“SELECT * FROM example ORDER BY ‘totalexp’ ASC”)
mysql_data_seek($query_result, $rank_number)
then use
mysql_fetch_row($query_result)

EDIT - Obviously edit it to fit your needs; example = table name; totalexp = the column name you are sorting by

There is a better way to do using nested queries which avoids fetching ALL the data from the database ;).
[/quote]I thought there was, I couldn’t think if the query that would do it though, so I just did it the other way. Feel free to point it out :P[/quote]

I would have posted it earlier but I wasn’t at home so didn’t have it handy :p. This is what I wrote to be used on the Emps-Scape highscores:

SET @rownum := 0;
SELECT * FROM ( SELECT @rownum := @rownum + 1 AS rank, username FROM highscores WHERE skill = ? ORDER BY level DESC, exp DESC LIMIT 1000 ) AS ranked_highscores WHERE username = ?;

It only reports ranks if you are in the top 1000, you can change that by changing the LIMIT clause.

Read full topic
